# The best wireless headphones for audio without aggravation

WIRED Recommends the best Bluetooth headphones, in-ears and wireless earbuds
you can buy in 2020

* * *

By [WIRED](/profile/wired)

31 Jan 2020

  * [ Facebook ](https://www.facebook.com/dialog/share?app_id=166725050017831&display=popup&href=https://www.wired.co.uk/article/best-bluetooth-headphones&redirect_uri=https://www.wired.co.uk/article/best-bluetooth-headphones&picture=https://wi-images.condecdn.net/image/GmbkV6q7JeX/crop/1440/0.5235602094240838/f/headphones-edit.jpg "facebook")

Friday 31 January 2020

![](/static/img/tiny.gif) ![](https://wi-

Maybe you’re the sort of person who gets tangled up in wires. Maybe you’re the
type who creates knots in them and breaks them as a result. Perhaps you’re
just not the sort who likes to be tied down.

No matter your motivation, this is the perfect time to get into a pair of
wireless headphones. The technology is proven, it’s more affordable than ever,
and some of the biggest names in headphones are ready to sell you a wire-free
passage to audio Nirvana. Mind you, there are some less illustrious, less
well-established brands able to do just that, too.

##### Advertisement

Convenience without compromise, audio without aggravation. Your perfect pair
of wireless headphones is right here.

## What are the best wireless headphones in 2020?

The **best wireless headphones** you can buy right now are the [Sennheiser
Momentum Wireless (£290)](https://amzn.to/2Osooep). They're stylish and
comfortable, with great specs and a capable, accomplished sound.

### Sennheiser Momentum Wireless

 **WIRED Recommends: Sennheiser's Momentum Wireless are a brilliantly
accomplished pair of headphones**

![](/static/img/tiny.gif) ![](https://wi-
images.condecdn.net/image/wzPP7mDD2jw/crop/405/f/momentum_3_ae_bt_black_isofront_rgb_red.jpg)

**Type:** Over-ear | **Wireless:** Yes | **Bluetooth:** aptX 5.0 | **Battery
life:** 17hr | **Remote:** n/a | **Finishes:** 2 | **Weight:** 305g |
**Cable:** 1.2m | **Noise cancelling:** Yes | **Sensitivity:** 103.65dB |
**Style:** Closed back

The third gen of **[Sennheiser's Momentum Wireless series
(£290)](https://amzn.to/2Osooep)** will require you to part with several
hundred pounds but in return, you get stylish wireless cans, covered in
sheepskin and with great specifications.

#### Read next

  * [The best baby monitors in 2020](/article/best-baby-monitors)

![](/static/img/tiny.gif) ![](https://wi-
images.condecdn.net/image/nwe1KeBkm5e/crop/200/square/f/best-baby.jpg)

###  The best baby monitors in 2020

* * *

By WIRED

The 2019 edition of the Momentum Wireless come feature packed too. We're
talking aptX Bluetooth 5.0, the neat Smart Control companion app, physical
controls on the right ear cup and the option to add voice assistant controls
from Siri, Google Assistant or - coming soon - Alexa.

None of which really account for Sennheiser's position in this list. Because
the fact of the matter is you won't get a more thrilling, detailed and poised
performance this side of £350. No matter what you throw at them, the Momentum
Wireless take it in their stride, whether that's driving forward with Childish
Gambino or tackling complex layers of texture and timbre in a spot of
Radiohead. We can't tell you enough what a confident and balanced listen this
is, they're fully in charge no matter the tempo or rhythmic idiosyncrasies.

Sennheiser pips our long-time favourites from Sony to the top-spot on pure
sound then. They do cost more than £100 over the current price of the XM3s
though, which are also worth considering if battery life or noise-cancelling
performance are more important to you. The noise cancelling, which has three
levels, is not the most thorough around but the top 'max' level is fairly
effective.

As for battery life, the Sennheiser's will last a respectable, if not
stunning, 17 hours versus 30+ hours elsewhere. Still, with this sonic
signature, we'll take the extra charging.

**Pros:** Energetic, expansive sound; comfortable; good control app  
**Cons:** So-so battery life; likewise the noise cancelling

### Sony WH-1000XM3

 **Superstar noise cancelling and sound at a great price**

![](/static/img/tiny.gif) ![](https://wi-

**Type:** Over-ear | **Wireless:** Yes | **Bluetooth:** aptX HD 4.2 |
**Battery life:** 30hr | **Remote:** n/a | **Finishes:** 2 | **Weight:** 255g
| **Cable:** 1.2m | **Noise cancelling:** Yes | **Sensitivity:** 104.5dB |
**Style:** Closed back

Yes, we realise more than £250 for a pair of headphones might stretch your
credulity. But just think about this: the **[Sony WH-1000XM3
(£249)](https://amzn.to/2LhMtRR)** top the lists of another of our headphones
guides, best noise cancelling headphones, for a reason. They are absolute
superstars.

By WIRED

In terms of wireless performance, they’re every bit as impressive here as they
are elsewhere. They pair rapidly, prove unshakably tenacious in maintaining
their wireless grip and then hand over a detailed, rhythmically efficient and
thoroughly entertaining presentation of all the music you enjoy listening to.

Add in touch control, Amazon Alexa voice assistance, USB-C for rapid charging
and Sony’s customary unburstable build quality, and the case is pretty much
watertight. In terms of striking a balance between performance, comfort,
functionality and price, the 1000MX3s hit the dead centre of the bullseye.

**Pros:** Extensive functionality; sturdy; excellent wireless sound  
 **Cons:** Feel quite large in situ

 **Price:** £249 | **[Check price on Amazon

### Apple AirPods Pro

 **The best wireless earbuds right now**

#### Read next

  * [The best cameras for travel, creative and street photography](/article/best-cameras)

![](/static/img/tiny.gif) ![](https://wi-
images.condecdn.net/image/A6ZR2aDRVxZ/crop/200/square/f/wired-recommends-
cameras-1.jpg)

###  The best cameras for travel, creative and street photography

* * *

By WIRED

![](/static/img/tiny.gif) ![](https://wi-
images.condecdn.net/image/3nzkoWA1yL5/crop/405/f/wr-headphone-update-1.jpg)

**Type:** In-ear | **Wireless:** Yes | **Bluetooth:** 5.0 | **Battery life:**
5hr (4.5hr NC/24hr from case) | **Finishes:** 3 | **Weight:** 5.4g each (45.6g
case) | **Water resistance:** IPX4 | **Noise cancelling:** Yes

"So good, it's almost annoying" we cried in our [review of the Apple AirPods
Pro](https://www.wired.co.uk/article/apple-airpods-pro-review). And they are
indeed a massive step-up from the previous generation of Apple buds with a
much welcome redesign, a considerable improvement in sound performance and
genuinely cracking noise-cancellation.

Most of what's worth talking about with the AirPods Pro comes down to Apple
responding (well) to previous criticism of the AirPods line. The now-iconic
(yet ridiculous looking) stems are now a full centimetre shorter. The
combination of the superb, balanced sound on offer and the very good noise
cancelling also now makes these the commuter's go-to.

Sure, the noise cancelling can't be adjusted and the ear tip test isn't as
clever as Cupertino thinks but for most people, this overall feature set will
be a real winner. With a decent transparency mode, built-in Siri for those who
want it and a new squeeze command that's more helpful than the old, hit-and-
miss tap controls, we can wholeheartedly recommend the AirPods Pro in a way
that we simply haven't been able to with Apple's wireless earbuds before.

### SoundMAGIC E11BT

 **Best in-ear under £50: Simply stupendous value for money**

![](/static/img/tiny.gif) ![](https://wi-
images.condecdn.net/image/2Xd9dkdXK8l/crop/405/f/7.jpg)

**Type:** In-ear | **Wireless:** Semi | **Bluetooth:** aptX 5.0 | **Battery
life:** 48-60hr | **Remote:** Yes | **Finishes:** 2 | **Weight:** 25g |
**Cable:** n/a |  
 **Noise cancelling:** No

#### Read next

  * [These are the best noise-cancelling headphones in 2020](/article/best-noise-cancelling-headphones)

![](/static/img/tiny.gif) ![](https://wi-
images.condecdn.net/image/D3WLYDBMW73/crop/200/square/f/hero-best-noise-
cancelling-8.jpg)

###  These are the best noise-cancelling headphones in 2020

* * *

By WIRED

Wireless in-ear headphones with a neckband, like the **[SoundMAGIC E11BTs
(£40)](https://amzn.to/2AWR9Iy)** , are a very sensible idea. The arrangement
keeps costs down, keeps earbud size down to non-laughable levels, and keeps
them stable should you risk breaking into a run.

But not many in-ear headphones represent the stupendous value for money of
SoundMAGIC. The company has plenty of previous where turning out affordable,
class-leading earbuds, and rearranging its brilliant E11s into a wireless
configuration hasn’t spoiled that run of form in the slightest. Quite the
opposite, in fact.

The E11BTs sound more accomplished than they have any right to. They’re a
balanced and quite vigorous listen, more than happy to dig in and punch
solidly if your music demands it. They give a decent impression of pace,
reveal ample detail and can turn their hand to more or less any type of music.
Want to cut down on wires without cutting too badly into your bank account?
You’ve come to the right place.

 **Pros:** Comfortable fit; hi-res DAC; aptX Bluetooth  
 **Cons:** At this price? None

 **Price:** £40 | **[Check price on Amazon](https://amzn.to/2AWR9Iy)**

### Urbanista Seattle

 **Best on-ear under £100: Stable connection; serious audio punch**

![](/static/img/tiny.gif) ![](https://wi-
images.condecdn.net/image/G9JzJmJkj1M/crop/405/f/4.jpg)

**Type:** On-ear | **Wireless:** Yes | **Bluetooth:** 4.1 | **Battery life:**
12hr | **Remote:** n/a | **Finishes:** 4 | **Weight:** 172g | **Cable:** 1.2m
|  
**Noise cancelling:** No

There is increasing choice in the sub-£100 wireless on-ear headphones arena.
But in terms of worthwhile performance, choice is quite severely curtailed. In
fact, we reckon that in the **[Urbanista Seattle
(£68)](https://amzn.to/2MTLvuX)** , you’re looking at Number One in a field of
one.

At this sort of money you can’t expect the most luxurious materials or the
most up-to-the-minute specification. And, sure enough, the Seattles are a
little bit plasticky and don’t have aptX Bluetooth - but they’re comfortable
enough, thanks to memory foam ear-pads, and their wireless connectivity is
solid and stable.

#### Read next

  * [The best barbecues and pizza ovens, gas and charcoal](/article/best-bbq-gas-and-charcoal)

![](/static/img/tiny.gif) ![](https://wi-
images.condecdn.net/image/R8lMmzmQM1a/crop/200/square/f/hero-wired-recommends-
bbqs-alt-3.jpg)

###  The best barbecues and pizza ovens, gas and charcoal

* * *

By WIRED

But what’s truly remarkable about the Seattles is the sound they make. They
carry enough bass weight (and control it well enough) to deliver serious
punch, they’re balanced enough in the midrange to give a vocalist the platform
to shine, and treble sounds bite without becoming coarse. For performance and
convenience on a budget, these remain the on-ears to beat.

**Pros:** Fine audio balance; grippy wireless performance  
 **Cons:** No aptX (which is nit-picking at this money)

 **Price:** £68 | **[Check price on Amazon](https://amzn.to/2MTLvuX) **

### Sennheiser Momentum Free

 **Best in-ear under £100: Effortless to listen to - and to wear**

![](/static/img/tiny.gif) ![](https://wi-
images.condecdn.net/image/95NVNbN7Bgo/crop/405/f/6.jpg)

#### Read next

  * [The (actually good) tech deals in Amazon’s Summer Sale](/article/amazon-summer-sale-2020)

![](/static/img/tiny.gif) ![](https://wi-
images.condecdn.net/image/23XaglX1YKO/crop/200/square/f/7.jpg)

###  The (actually good) tech deals in Amazon’s Summer Sale

* * *

By WIRED

**Type:** In-ear | **Wireless:** Semi | **Bluetooth:** aptX 4.2 | **Battery
life:** 6hr **Remote:** Yes | **Finishes:** 1 | **Weight:** 40g | **Cable:**
1.2m | **Noise cancelling:** No

The Sennheiser Momentum range is extensive to the point it can be difficult to
tell some models apart. What’s important to know about the **[Momentum Free
(£84)](https://amzn.to/2Gu0cmZ)** is that the earbuds are connected by a slim,
adjustable cable - physically, that’s how they can be distinguished from the
Momentum In-Ear Wireless and Momentum True Wireless in this list. And then
there’s the price difference, of course.

What’s less easy to discern is any particular compromise when it comes to the
sound the Momentum Frees make. They’re a nimble listen, able to establish
breathing space for solid bass, expressive midrange and crisp treble -
separation and focus are really impressive. They handle rhythms well enough to
get your head nodding, and flow along very naturally.

They don’t look like a lot of headphones for the money, it’s true - but they
definitely sound like it.

**Also consider:** The **[Sennheiser Momentum in-ear
Wireless](https://amzn.to/2E4K1KX)** have dropped in price to around £119.
It's a neckband design, which you may not like, but it provides stability and
across-the-board audio talent.

**  
Pros:** Effortless to listen to; equally effortless to wear  
 **Cons:** So-so battery life

 **Price:** £84 | **[Check price on Amazon](https://amzn.to/2RWFLV1) |
[Very](https://www.very.co.uk/sennheiser-momentum-free-in-ear-bluetooth-
headphones-with-bluetooth-42nbspqualcommreg-aptxtrade-integrated-remote-and-
up-to-6-hour-battery-life-blackred/1600259424.prd) |
[Argos](https://www.argos.co.uk/product/7644720) **

### AKG N60NC Wireless

 **Best on-ear under £150: Well regarded AKGs go Bluetooth**

![](/static/img/tiny.gif) ![](https://wi-
images.condecdn.net/image/jrEnEONNDeR/crop/405/f/3.jpg)

**Type:** On-ear | **Wireless:** Yes | **Bluetooth:** aptX 4.0 | **Battery
life:** 15hr | **Remote:** Yes | **Finishes:** 1 | **Weight:** 199.4g |
**Cable:** 1.2m | **Noise cancelling:** Yes | **Sensitivity:** 111dB |
**Style:** Closed back

Even expensive headphones don’t have too many boxes to tick before they can
properly be considered contenders. Proper build quality, decent comfort and
great sound should do it. If you chuck in wireless operation and [noise-
cancelling](https://www.wired.co.uk/article/best-noise-cancelling-headphones),
too, then the deal is sealed. Which brings us to the **[AKG N60NC Wireless
(£118)](https://amzn.to/32B6BWm)**.

They’re - hey! - a wireless version of the very well regarded N60NCs, and they
retain all of their cheaper relative’s talents: rich, smooth and detailed
sound, a handy combination of lightweight and durable build, and active noise-
cancelling effective enough to make even the longest-haul flight tolerable.

And, of course, the wireless connectivity makes them uber-convenient. Using
aptX Bluetooth means clean, open and punchy sound from your smartphone, and
there’s even a cable in case your battery runs out of juice. If our outright
favourite Sennheisers are a bit pricey, or a bit big, you’ll find the AKGs are
made to satisfy.

 **Also consider:** Well screwed together, comfortable even for the longest
listening sessions, and with proper battery life, the £75 **[AKG
Y50BTs](https://amzn.to/2NkWBtV)** put the cherry on the top with outstanding
sound quality.

 **Pros:** Great build; great features; great sound  
 **Cons:** Arguably don’t look like the RRP

**Price:** £118 | **[Check price on Amazon](https://amzn.to/32B6BWm)**

### AKG N700 NCM2

 **Outstanding build, looks and sound without breaking the bank**

![](/static/img/tiny.gif) ![](https://wi-
images.condecdn.net/image/6jGPdrZYJod/crop/405/f/wr-headphone-update-2.jpg)

**Type:** Over-ear | **Wireless:** Yes | **Bluetooth:** 4.2 | **Battery
life:** 23 - 32 hours | **Remote:** n/a | **Finishes:** 1 | **Weight:** 277g |
**Noise cancelling:** Yes, sort of | **Sensitivity:** 110dB | **Style:**
Closed back

Got proper money for a proper pair of wireless headphones but don’t want to
walk about the place looking like a Cyberman? Then you need to consider
**[AKG’s N700 NCM2 headphones (£199)](https://www.samsung.com/uk/mobile-
accessories/wireless-akg-headphones-n700ncm2/)** \- they’ve got almost
everything you want in a package that doesn’t double the width of your head.

The looks are good and mercifully discreet; the feel is great thanks to sturdy
plastics, steel accents and soft, comfy pleather; the finish is robust.
There’s active noise-cancelling on board (although it’s nothing like as
effective as found on some massive alternatives from Bose, Microsoft and
Sony), and reliable, responsive voice control. They’ve a nice control app with
some worthwhile EQ functions, Bluetooth 4.2 wireless connectivity and between
23 and 32 hours of use from a single charge (depending on how many features
you’re using at once). Unlike bigger, slightly pricier alternatives, though,
there are no touch controls.

What really swings it for the AKGs is sound quality. They’re a big-boned and
expansive listen, with more than enough low frequency presence to trouble your
sinuses and an extremely deft, detailed midrange. The top of the frequency
range is well judged too, and the AKGs knit a song together convincingly -
they’re very talented where presenting a tune as a unified whole is concerned.

**  
Pros:** Compact and robust; rock-solid connectivity; big, punchy sound  
**Cons:** Humdrum noise-cancelling; no touch controls

**Price:** £199 | **[Check price on
Samsung](https://www.samsung.com/uk/mobile-accessories/wireless-akg-
headphones-n700ncm2/) | [Argos](https://www.argos.co.uk/product/3110090)**

### Jaybird Vista

 **The best for running: Exercise-proof and hard to dislodge**

![](/static/img/tiny.gif) ![](https://wi-
images.condecdn.net/image/AAwVXD4RQKe/crop/405/f/wired-wireless-earphone-
updates-2.jpg)

Jaybird

**Type:** In-ear | **Wireless:** Yes | **Bluetooth:** 5.0 | **Battery life:**
6hr (10hr from case) | **Remote:** n/a | **Finishes:** 3 | **Weight:** 6g each
(45g case) | **Water resistance:** IPX7 | **Noise cancelling:** No

Completely, truly wireless in-ear headphones might seem a counter-intuitive
choice for the sporty user. After all, it doesn’t matter how good a headphone
sounds if it keeps falling out of your ear.

But despite being a true wireless design, the **[Jaybird Vista
(£145)](https://amzn.to/2Me8wfn)** are a downright brilliant choice. Thanks to
interchangeable tips and fins (the latter to hold the earbuds steady in your
ear) they’re easy to get comfortable and hard to dislodge. And thanks to some
very sympathetic tuning and adjustable EQs in the Jaybird control app, they
sound really good. By which we mean thoroughly punchy, perky and engaging even
when the blood is pumping in your ears.

Waterproof and sweatproof, with six hours of battery life (plus another ten
from the charging carry-case), they’re ready to come along on even the most
optimistic workout. And thanks to quick charge that means five minutes plugged
in will get you another hour of running, they’re a welcome addition to your
fitness regime.
